abstract.p: Vibration occurring during machining is a major limitation to the productivity and quality of products. The dynamic interaction between the cutter and the workpiece during a turning process causes self-excited vibration. If the level of vibration is sufficiently high, poor surface quality of the workpiece and excessive tool wear can occur. This article presents a dynamic model for the vibration in turning operations taking into account the time-dependent reduction of workpiece diameter and the regenerative chatter mechanism. The workpiece is modelled as a beam rotating about its longitudinal axis and the cutter provides a moving load that is a source of parametric excitation. Simulated numerical examples are presented. Turning experiments are conducted that demonstrate vibration and chatter in turning operations. It is found through comparison between the theoretical and numerical results that the established dynamic model can predict the vibration pattern of the workpieces fairly well but underestimates the magnitude of workpiece oscillation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During a metal turning process, complex dynamic interaction takes place at the interface between the workpiece and the cutter. As a result, chatter may occur. Analytical solutions for turning chatter are mostly based on the regenerative chatter mechanism: as the cutter encounters a wavy surface of a workpiece left from the previous cut, the undulations generated in the previous revolution affect the cutter–workpiece vibration and may cause dynamic instability.1

Several theories have been proposed to explain the occurrence of chatter instability for optimizing certain combinations of process parameters, i.e. feed rate, depth of cut, rotational speed, variation of chip thickness and variation of cutting force. Tobias and Fishwick2 proposed a linear model of a single degree of freedom and identified the mechanism for the onset of chatter. Tlusty and Polacek3 and Merrit4 investigated the conditions of stability for the cutter, structural dynamics of machines and feedback of previous cuts on the surface of the workpiece as the main sources of chatter. The regenerative chatter with a simplified scenario in turning operations was explained in the study of Tarng et al.5,6 Several dynamic models for regenerative chatter have been put forward, for example, in the studies of Altintas7 and Tlusty.8 Chen et al.9 modelled the workpiece as a flexible beam and the tool as a one degree-of-freedom mass-spring-damper system for orthogonal cutting. They presented a stability analysis of turning a cantilever beam.

In practical turning processes, the nonlinear relationship between the cutting force and chip thickness shows the subcritical Hopf bifurcation phenomenon, as investigated by Tobias et al.10 Because of the nonlinearity and possible loss of contact between the cutter and the workpiece,11,12 chatter appears as high-amplitude bounded oscillations called limit cycle or a subcritical phenomenon. The nature of the phenomenon was predicted by Moon et al.13 Moreover, Stépán14 and Fofana15 made further research into the nonlinear dynamics of regenerative chatter.

For chatter suppression in a turning process, many methods have been put forward. Tarng et al.16 presented a new spindle speed regulation method to avoid regenerative chatter, while Pakdemirli and Ulsoy,17 Al-Regib et al.18 and Insperger and Stépán19 applied sinusoidal modulation of spindle speed for machine tool chatter suppression, using different methods for determining the spindle speed characteristics. Another one was an active control method, in which a piezoelectric inertia actuator mounted on the cutting tool as a tuned vibration absorber was used.20 Sims21 developed an analytical tuning methodology that used absorbers for vibration reduction. Ganguli et al.22 found that different spindle speeds caused changes in the system damping, resulting in different levels of stability limits at different spindle speeds. The damping and speed determined the thickness of the chip. Hence, active damping with velocity feedback was adopted as the chatter control strategy. Chen et al.23 introduced a method of employing a magnetic bearing connected with the cutter for actuation and simulated the dynamics of a flexible rotor to suppress the onset of chatter. In many studies of regenerative chatter, the cutter and the workpiece were modelled each as a lumped mass system with one or two degrees of freedom, where the cutting force is described as a function of relative vibrations between the current and previous passes.

On the other hand, some other researchers modelled the workpiece as a rotating beam subjected to various moving loads. This kind of models has been studied for a long time. Lee et al.24 and Katz et al.25 seemed to be the first researchers who studied vibration of a rotating beam excited by a transverse load moving at constant speed based on the Euler, Rayleigh and Timoshenko beam theories. Their works initiated another line of research briefly reviewed below.

Huang et al.26,27 investigated the dynamic response of a rotating cylindrical shell and a spinning orthotropic beam subjected to harmonic moving loads. Argento and Scott28 studied a rotating Timoshenko beam under a moving distributed surface force at acceleration. Zu and Han29 also examined vibration of a rotating Timoshenko beam, which has general boundary conditions. Parametric stability of a rotor-disk system under a non-moving dynamic axial load was analysed in the study of Sinha.30 Lee31 introduced a constant non-moving axial force and showed it had a significant effect on the dynamic response when the force is not small in relation to the Euler buckling load. Random moving loads were considered in the study of Zibdeh and Juma.32 El-Saeidy33 included boundary conditions of nonlinear stiffness due to clearance in rolling bearings. He also brought in moving bending moments. Sheu and Yang34 calculated the dynamic response of a spinning Rayleigh beam with mass eccentricity but with stationary loads. Dssanayake and Suh35 built a three-dimensional model for the vibration of workpiece modelled as three rotors connected by a shaft, induced by a nonlinear regenerative force. He examined dynamic stability in different stages. Vibration of a rotating Rayleigh beam and Timoshenko beam subjected to a moving load was analysed in the study of Ouyang and Wang.36,37 A moving bending couple as a result of translating a surface axial force component to the neutral axis of the beam was included. It was found that this bending couple could have a significant influence on the dynamic response of the beams. Kotaiah and Srinivas38 developed an analytical stability model of regenerative chatter in orthogonal turning process, in which the cutting tool is simplified as a single-degree-of-freedom oscillator, and the workpiece is represented by a discrete finite element beam model.

One shortcoming of the aforementioned models is that reduction of workpiece diameter, and hence mass and stiffness of the workpiece are neglected, even though material in the form of chips is removed during a turning operation. Decreasing workpiece diameter was shown to affect the fundamental natural frequency of a workpiece.39 It is likely that the time-dependent reduction of the workpiece diameter could influence its dynamic response and thus should be studied. In this article, a dynamic model is presented for vibration of a rotating Rayleigh beam with a time-dependent decreasing diameter subjected to an axially moving cutting force. The workpiece has three sections of different diameters, while the cutting force is described as a function of relative oscillations during the current and previous passes and was obtained from measured dynamometer data. As a result of the moving cutting force and the decreasing diameter of the workpiece as the sources of parametric excitation, self-excited vibration occurs. Vibration tests of turning operations are also carried out to illustrate the effect of dynamic depth of cut during machining.

This article is organized as follows. The dynamic model of a workpiece in a turning operation is described in section ‘Dynamic model’. The formulation of coupled equations of motion with time delay is derived from Hamilton’s principle in section ‘Mathematical formulation and calculation’. The experimental set-up and procedure is described in the fourth section. Dedicated experiments are conducted on a lathe. The numerical solutions of the equations of motion are computed and discussed in section ‘Numerical analysis and results’. The theoretical results of the model are compared with the experimental results and confirm the validity of the model established in this article. Conclusions are given in the final section.

sec.title: Dynamic model
sec.p:
In turning operations, there are two moving components, a cutter and a workpiece. The workpiece is clamped to a chuck on one end and is supported at the tailstock on another end. To a space-fixed observer, the workpiece has a rotary motion, while the cutter travels along a straight line in the axial direction. As a result of cutting, the workpiece has three distinct sections: un-machined, being-machined and machined, as shown in Figure 1, where l is the full length of the workpiece, l1 the length of unmachined section, l2 the length of unmachined and being-machined sections of the workpiece together and s(t) the variable distance from the spindle to the location of the moving cutter. Figure 1.
Workpiece model.

As shown in Figure 1, the circular workpiece is rotating around its longitudinal axis, and is subjected to a cutting force with three orthogonal components Fx, Fy and Fz moving along the x axis on the surface of the workpiece. A rectangular inertial frame is used as the coordinate system. The deflections of the rotating workpiece in the y and z directions caused by the cutting force are denoted by v and w.

Because the workpiece is treated as a beam, the axial component Fx of the cutting force has to be translated to the neutral axis of the beam. As a result, a bending couple Mz is produced as36 (1) where r2=(r1+r)/2 is the average radius of the cone-shaped being-machined section, r1 the radius of the un-machined section and r the radius of the machined section, as shown in Figure 1.

Concerning the being-machined section of the workpiece, the shape of the cone is dependent on the side cutting edge angle cs of the cutter and some technical requirements. The range of cs used is from 0° to 45°. Due to the vibration of the workpiece and the cutter during the turning operation, the cutter cuts a wavy surface on the being-machined section. When the instability condition is met, regenerative chatter will happen on the wavy surface of the cone and has a significant influence on the cutting force components in the x, y and z directions, shown in Figure 2. In this article, the cutter is assumed to be a rigid body and always in contact with the workpiece. If separation is considered, forces Fy and Fz must be monitored. If either drops to zero, free vibration ensures. Then, the deflection of the workpiece must be monitored to see if it will reengage with the cutter. In all the tests carried out by the authors, no separation has been detected and hence this assumption is considered valid within this investigation. Influence of vibration on the workpiece in the x axis is ignored. sec.title: Experimental set-up and procedure
sec.p:
The experimental set-up is shown schematically in Figure 3 and pictured in Figure 4. The test hardware used is commercially available. A Brüel & Kjær’s PULSE-Type 3560E data acquisition system with 16 channels is used for signal processing of the cutting force and vibration with the help of processing software. Two eddy-current transducers (3300 XL 8 mm Proximity Transducer System made by Bently Nevada) are fixed on the tool carriage connected with a fastening apparatus, which are kept at a distance within 2 mm from the machined surface of the workpiece in the y and z directions. The distance between the eddy-current transducers and the tool tip in the x axis direction is kept within 10 mm. The dynamometer YDX-III9702 (made by the Institute of Sensing and Control at Dalian University of Technology) is installed under the tool post, which is specially designed to fit the dynamometer assembly. The cutter is synchronously driven with the dynamometer and the eddy-current transducers from the right-hand side of the workpiece to the chuck. The sampling frequency of measurement is 8 kHz. Figure 3.
Schematic illustration of test set-up. Figure 4.
Two views of the experimental rig (photos).

To determine the cutting forces and vibration of the workpiece under different cutting conditions, dry turning operations were performed on CA6140 lathe. The tool holder used in the experiment is PSSNR2525M12. The quadrangle carbide insert P10 coated with the optimal combination of MT-TiCN, Al2O3 and TiN is SNMG120404-PM with 0.4 mm nose radius. Other cutting parameters of the tool are side cutting edge angle cs=45deg, inclination angle ia=0deg, and normal rake angle γn=10deg. The workpieces tested are in two different diameters and 0.5 m in length, as shown in Table 1. The workpiece material is AISI 1045 steel, and its hardness is HB190. Table 1.

The cutting conditions are listed in Table 1. The rotating speed, feed rate and depth of cut are carefully selected for different cutting conditions. D is the diameter of the unmachined workpiece and equal to 2r1.

Vibration of the workpiece is due to the cutting force and its travel in the longitudinal direction and (relatively) in the circumferential direction in the turning operation. These two factors together affect vibration of the workpiece. Moreover, regenerative chatter may also occur. Appropriate cutting condition and dimension of the workpiece are used in the experiments.

The dynamometer is used to measure the dynamic cutting forces. At the same time, two eddy-current transducers measure the vibration of the workpiece near the being-machined cross-section in the y and the z directions. All sensors simultaneously move along the longitudinal axis of the workpiece with the tool carriage. Hence, the being-machined section of the workpiece is tracked and its vibration measured. On occasions, the vibration response signal may not be solely due to the moving cutting force. Other factors such as the vibration of the spindle of the lath due to power transmitted via the gear and of the tool carriage moving on its adjustable horizontal metal rail with clearance, and vibration of the tool holder may contribute to the vibration signal measured and sever to contaminate the true workpiece vibration signal. Therefore, before each formal test of vibration in turning operation is conducted, a pretest is carried out with the workpiece rotating and the cutter making one complete travel without cutting. The vibration signal of the pretest is measured in order to analyze the effect of these variations on the measured signals.

In the turning operation, vibration of the workpiece subjected to three moving dynamic cutting force components was recorded at different cutting conditions. Two tests were conducted in different cutting conditions of Table 1 in the dry run. The five channels of the 3560E were simultaneously used for data acquisition, of which three channels were for the cutting force signals, another two channels were for collecting vibration signals during each cut.

Figure 5 shows the photograph of the machined workpiece in Test No. 1. The dynamic responses of the workpiece in the y and z directions are measured at the being-machined position during turning, and the results are plotted in Figure 6(a) and (b). Because of the gap between the guideway and the carriage that slides along it, the carriage moves the tool in a direction that is only nearly parallel to the longitudinal direction. This extra deflection, obtained from a dry turning run before the proper turning process, is deducted from the tested data. Figure 5.
Workpiece of Test No. 1 after machining. Figure 6.
Deflections of Test No. 1 in time domain.

In Test No. 2, a bigger depth of cut and a smaller feed rate than those of Test No. 1 are used (Table 1). The workpiece after machining is shown in Figure 7, in which chatter marks can be seen in the middle region of the workpiece. Chatter is large-amplitude irregular vibration happening during machining shown in the large dynamic response in Figure 8. Figure 7.
Workpiece of Test No. 2 after machining. Figure 8.
Deflections of Test No. 2 in time domain.

The dynamic responses vp and wp of the workpiece at the moving cutter location (in the y and z directions, respectively) are computed from equations (10) and (11).

The effect of decreasing radius of the workpiece on its dynamic response is studied, when the radius is constant and time-varying, respectively. r0 is the radius of the workpiece used in the numerical analysis. Accordingly, there are three cases: (1) the radius of workpiece in this case is taken to be that of the beam after machining r0=r and is constant, i.e. r1=r2=r=16.75mm; (2) the radius of the workpiece in this case is taken to be that of the original unmachined workpiece (r0=r1) and is also constant, i.e. r=r2=r1=18.25mm; (3) the radius of the workpiece is time-varying as cutting progresses with the nominal depth of cut h0=1.5mm, i.e. r0=rx. Figure 9 shows the numerical results obtained at Ω=1250r/min, the feed rate f=0.3mm/rev, and the moving speed u = 250 mm/s. Clear consideration of time-dependent reduction of workpiece diameter makes a noticeable difference in the dynamic response, as shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.

The numerical results of the dynamic responses vp and wp of the workpiece at actual cutting condition of Tests Nos 1 and 2 are computed from equations (10) and (11) and shown in Figures 10 and 11, respectively. In Figure 10, the nominal depth of cut is 1.5 mm, feed rate 0.3 mm/rev, rotational speed 1250 r/min, and radius of the unmachined workpiece 18.25 mm. Figure 10(a) and (b) shows a similar pattern but different magnitudes in the dynamic response, because the cutting force in the z direction is greater than that in the y direction. Figure 10.
Dynamic response computed at r1 = 18.25 mm, u = 6.25 mm/s (Ω = 1250 r/min, h0 = 1.5 mm, f = 0.3 mm/rev). Figure 11.
Dynamic response computed at r1 = 17.5 mm, u = 4.17 mm/s (Ω = 1000 r/min, h0 = 3 mm, f = 0.2 mm/rev).

In comparison of the dynamic responses vp and wp of the workpiece in Figure 10 with those in Figure 6, it can be seen that the deformation patterns are fairly similar. However, the measured deflections are greater than the theoretical ones. It is believed that the theoretical model is stiffer as the chuck is represented by a clamped boundary and the tail stock support is represented by a simple support in the theoretical model. The oscillatory parts of the deflections are also greater in the measured values than in the theoretical values partly for the same reason. Another reason is that the measured data contain vibration from other sources, such as from the bearing clearance and non-rigid guideway.

In Figure 11, the cutting conditions of Test No. 2 are that the nominal depth of cut is 3 mm, the feed rate 0.2 mm/rev, rotation speed 1000 r/min, and radius of the unmachined workpiece is 17.5 mm which is less than r1 in Test No. 1. The nominal depth of cut in Figure 11 is bigger than that in Figure 10. Hence, a bigger cutting force is acting on the workpiece and a greater amplitude in the fluctuating part of the deflections in vp and wp results in Figure 11.
Comparing the theoretical results in Figure 11 with the average deflections in Figure 8, the amplitudes of deflection in vp and wp are slightly different.

When the moving speed of the cutter increases to 125 and 250 mm/s, respectively, and the other cutting conditions are kept unchanged, the dynamic response obtained from equations (10) and (11) is shown in Figures 12 and 13. It can be seen by comparing Figures 12 and 13 with Figure 10, the amplitudes in the fluctuating part of the deflection vp or wp in Figures 12 and 13 become larger as the moving speed of the cutting forces increases. This is thought to be due to the moving-load effect. Figure 12.
Dynamic response computed at r1 = 18.25 mm, u = 125 mm/s (Ω = 1250 r/min, h0 = 1.5 mm, f = 0.3 mm/rev). Figure 13.
Dynamic response computed at r1 = 18.25 mm, u = 250 mm/s (Ω = 1250 r/min, h0 = 1.5 mm, f = 0.3 mm/rev).

When the regenerative effect is excluded and thus the term v(t-τ) is ignored in equations (10) and (11) for the same cutting condition as Figure 10, the dynamic response is given in Figure 14 and is seen to be smoother. This suggests that without the regenerative effect, the workpiece surface should be less rough. Figure 14.
Dynamic response computed at r1 = 18.25 mm, u = 250 mm/s without v(t-τ) (Ω = 1250 r/min, h0 = 1.5 mm, f = 0.3 mm/rev).

Examining all the numerical results, it may be concluded that the predicted and measured patterns of time-histories of workpiece vibration agree fairly well but the magnitudes are not so close to each other, in particular when the large vibration (chatter) is excited during the experiments. An improved dynamic model that considers nonlinear cutting force may be needed. The experimental conditions should also be improved.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article studies self-excited vibration of workpieces in turning operations. The workpiece is modelled as a circular beam rotating around its longitudinal axis in clamped–pinned boundary conditions and the cutter provides a moving load with three perpendicular force components. The dynamic model includes the influence on vibration of the time-dependent reduction of workpiece diameter and the regenerative chatter mechanism. The numerical results show that the regenerative term v(t-τ) has some effect on the dynamic response of the workpiece during the turning process. The moving speed u of the cutting force also influences the dynamic response of the workpiece. Hence, the suitable feed rate should be used to reduce vibration of the workpiece.

Two turning experiments are performed, and cutting forces are extracted from measured data by a dynamometer. The dynamic model displays a similar pattern to that of the measured vibration but underestimates the magnitude of fluctuation because its clamped–pinned boundary conditions are much stiffer than the true boundary condition at the chuck and the tail stock. This underestimation may be attributed to the stiffer boundary condition used in the theoretical model, perhaps the nonlinear nature of the real cutting force and measured vibration signal that may contain vibration from other sources not included in the dynamic model. Using more realistic boundary conditions and more sophisticated cutting force models should improve the results of the dynamic models and will be the authors’ next research topics.
